required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Controlled Trial to Compare Implant Migration of the MIS Stem Versus The Synergy Total Hip System by Radiostereometric Analysis

brief_summary.textblock:
The objectives of this study are to assess migration of the MIS Stem compared to the Synergy Hip System using Radiostereometric Analysis (RSA), and to assess the long-term safety and effectiveness of the study device. This study will document any device-related surgical or post-operative complications and adverse radiographic observations.
Subjects meeting the entrance criteria specified in this protocol will be randomized as they become available.

detailed_description.textblock: The purpose of the current investigation is to compare migration of the device after implantation with a modular, short hip stem called the "MIS Stem" or a standard THA using the Synergy Hip System using RSA. The intended use of this product is for patients with inflammatory and non-inflammatory degenerative joint disease who require a primary total hip replacement.

primary_outcome.measure: Migration of the MIS Femoral Neck Stem Compared to the Synergy Hip System Using RSA (Translational Movement)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Discharge (baseline), 6 weeks, 3 and 6 months, 1 and 2 years postoperative, change from baseline at 2 years reported
primary_outcome.description: Migration, or micromovement of the implant, was measured using RSA to compare the modular, short hip stem called the MIS Stem against a standard THA using Synergy Hip System.

primary_outcome.measure: Migration of the MIS Femoral Neck Stem Compared to the Synergy Hip System Using RSA (Rotational Movement)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Discharge (baseline), 6 weeks, 3 and 6 months, 1 and 2 years postoperative, change from baseline at 2 years reported
primary_outcome.description: Migration, or micromovement of the implant, was measured using RSA to compare the modular, short hip stem called the MIS Stem against a standard THA using Synergy Hip System.

secondary_outcome.description: The HHS is a physician tool to measure how a subject is doing after their hip was replaced. The HHS had a total range of 0-100 points and consisted of categories to assess Pain, Function, Absence of Deformity, Range of Motion, and Total Score. Each category was summarized and stratified into scores of Excellent (90-100), Good (80-89), Fair (70-79), Poor (60-69), and Very Poor (<60). Higher scores delineated better results for the subject.

secondary_outcome.measure: 3 Months Postoperative Total Harris Hip Score (HHS)
secondary_outcome.description: The HHS is a physician tool to measure how a subject is doing after their hip was replaced. secondary_outcome.measure: Preoperative Hip Disability Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (HOOS)
secondary_outcome.description: The HOOS was a questionnaire that the subject completed focusing on hip pain, stiffness, and function relating to osteoarthritis of the hip. The HOOS consisted of 40 items assessing 5 subscales; Symptoms and Stiffness, Pain, Function of Daily Living, Function in Sport and Recreation, and hip-related Quality of Life. Pain included 10 items with a total score of 40 points Symptoms included 5 items with a total score of 20 points Function of Daily Living included 17 items with a total score of 68 points Function in Sport and Recreation included 4 items with a total score of 16 points Hip-related Quality of Life included 4 items with a total score of 16 points Each subscore was transformed into a worst-to-best scale (0-100), where 100 indicated no symptoms and 0 indicated extreme symptoms.

secondary_outcome.measure: 3 Months Postoperative Hip Disability Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (HOOS)

Radiographs were obtained from the anteroposterior (AP) view as well as the lateral view.
Radiographs were obtained from the anteroposterior (AP) view as well as the lateral view.

Radiographs were obtained from the anteroposterior (AP) view as well as the lateral view.

arm_group.description: Subject will be randomized to either MIS or Synergy implant.
Subject will be randomized to either Synergy or MIS implant.

study_pop.textblock: The purpose of the current investigation is to compare migration of the device after implantation with a modular, short hip stem called the "MIS Stem" or a standard THA using the Synergy Hip System using RSA. The intended use of this product is for patients with inflammatory and non-inflammatory degenerative joint disease who require a primary total hip replacement.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Subject has hip disease that requires a total hip arthroplasty.
- Subject is willing to consent to participation in the study.
- Subject plans to be available for follow-up through study duration.
- Subject is of stable health and is free of or treated and stabilized for any condition that would prose excessive operating risk.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Subject has insufficient femoral bone stock.
- Subject has had major non-arthroscopic surgery to the study hip.
- Subject has physical, emotional or neurological conditions that would compromise the subjects compliance with postoperative rehabilitation and follow-up.
- Subject has a known sensitivity to materials in the device.

overall_official.affiliation: Vice President, Global Clinical Strategy and Global Clinical Operations

facility.name: London Health Sciences Center- University Hospital

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Subjects were enrolled by 1 investigator in Canada. The study period was from 30 Jun 2009 to 22 Apr 2016.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Preoperative evaluation was conducted following signing of the ICF but prior to randomization. A total of 41 subjects had surgery for either MIS Stem or Synergy implantation.

group.title: MIS Femoral Neck Stem
group.description: Designed to minimize the removal of bone from the femoral canal and the proximal neck. Along with a shortened length, the femoral stem uses a modular neck that allows for optimizing the offset angle to allow customization during surgery to better fit each patient. The modular neck features a standard taper consistent with various head options.

group.title: Synergy Hip System
group.description: Standard total hip arthroplasty (THA) using total hip system.

drop_withdraw_reason.title: Revision due to femoral stem loosening

baseline.population: 43 hips were randomized into the study, with 2 hips excluded, resulting in a total of 41 hips (4 bilateral hips) enrolled in the study - 20 Synergy hips and 21 MIS Stem hips

group.title: MIS Femoral Neck Stem
group.description: Designed to minimize the removal of bone from the femoral canal and the proximal neck. Along with a shortened length, the femoral stem uses a modular neck that allows for optimizing the offset angle to allow customization during surgery to better fit each patient. The modular neck features a standard taper consistent with various head options.

group.title: Synergy Hip System
group.description: Standard total hip arthroplasty (THA) using total hip system.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

class.title: Avascular necrosis: A unilateral hip joint disease
Osteoarthritis: B1 bilateral hip joint disease

outcome.title: Migration of the MIS Femoral Neck Stem Compared to the Synergy Hip System Using RSA (Translational Movement)
outcome.description: Migration, or micromovement of the implant, was measured using RSA to compare the modular, short hip stem called the MIS Stem against a standard THA using Synergy Hip System.
outcome.time_frame: Discharge (baseline), 6 weeks, 3 and 6 months, 1 and 2 years postoperative, change from baseline at 2 years reported
outcome.population: Statistical comparisons were done using data from hips with all with RSA information at 2 years (20 MIS and 18 Synergy).

Each category was summarized and stratified into scores of Excellent (90-100), Good (80-89), Fair (70-79), Poor (60-69), and Very Poor (<60). Higher scores delineated better results for the subject.

outcome.title: Preoperative Hip Disability Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (HOOS)
outcome.description: The HOOS was a questionnaire that the subject completed focusing on hip pain, stiffness, and function relating to osteoarthritis of the hip. The HOOS consisted of 40 items assessing 5 subscales; Symptoms and Stiffness, Pain, Function of Daily Living, Function in Sport and Recreation, and hip-related Quality of Life. Pain included 10 items with a total score of 40 points Symptoms included 5 items with a total score of 20 points Function of Daily Living included 17 items with a total score of 68 points Function in Sport and Recreation included 4 items with a total score of 16 points Hip-related Quality of Life included 4 items with a total score of 16 points Each subscore was transformed into a worst-to-best scale (0-100), where 100 indicated no symptoms and 0 indicated extreme symptoms.
outcome.population: Data from hips with all with RSA information at pre-operative visit (21 MIS and 20 Synergy).

measure.population: Data from hips with all with RSA information at 1 year (21 MIS and 15 Synergy).

outcome.title: 2 Years Postoperative Hip Disability Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (HOOS)
outcome.description: The HOOS was a questionnaire that the subject completed focusing on hip pain, stiffness, and function relating to osteoarthritis of the hip. The HOOS consisted of 40 items assessing 5 subscales; Symptoms and Stiffness, Pain, Function of Daily Living, Function in Sport and Recreation, and hip-related Quality of Life. Pain included 10 items with a total score of 40 points Symptoms included 5 items with a total score of 20 points Function of Daily Living included 17 items with a total score of 68 points Function in Sport and Recreation included 4 items with a total score of 16 points Hip-related Quality of Life included 4 items with a total score of 16 points Each subscore was transformed into a worst-to-best scale (0-100), where 100 indicated no symptoms and 0 indicated extreme symptoms.
outcome.population: Data from hips with all with RSA information at 2 years (21 MIS and 16 Synergy).

group.title: MIS Femoral Neck Stem
group.description: Designed to minimize the removal of bone from the femoral canal and the proximal neck. Along with a shortened length, the femoral stem uses a modular neck that allows for optimizing the offset angle to allow customization during surgery to better fit each patient. The modular neck features a standard taper consistent with various head options.

group.title: Synergy Hip System
group.description: Standard total hip arthroplasty (THA) using total hip system.

outcome.title: Migration of the MIS Femoral Neck Stem Compared to the Synergy Hip System Using RSA (Rotational Movement)
outcome.description: Migration, or micromovement of the implant, was measured using RSA to compare the modular, short hip stem called the MIS Stem against a standard THA using Synergy Hip System.
outcome.time_frame: Discharge (baseline), 6 weeks, 3 and 6 months, 1 and 2 years postoperative, change from baseline at 2 years reported
outcome.population: Statistical comparisons were done using data from hips with all with RSA information at 2 years (20 MIS and 18 Synergy).

group.title: MIS Femoral Neck Stem
group.description: Designed to minimize the removal of bone from the femoral canal and the proximal neck. Along with a shortened length, the femoral stem uses a modular neck that allows for optimizing the offset angle to allow customization during surgery to better fit each patient. The modular neck features a standard taper consistent with various head options.

group.title: Synergy Hip System
group.description: Standard total hip arthroplasty (THA) using total hip system.

measure.title: Migration of the MIS Femoral Neck Stem Compared to the Synergy Hip System Using RSA (Rotational Movement)
measure.description: Migration, or micromovement of the implant, was measured using RSA to compare the modular, short hip stem called the MIS Stem against a standard THA using Synergy Hip System.
measure.population: Statistical comparisons were done using data from hips with all with RSA information at 2 years (20 MIS and 18 Synergy).

reported_events.time_frame: From signed consent to the completion of the study at the 5-year follow-up visit, or early termination/subject withdrawal, whichever came first.

group.title: MIS Femoral Neck Stem
group.description: Designed to minimize the removal of bone from the femoral canal and the proximal neck. Along with a shortened length, the femoral stem uses a modular neck that allows for optimizing the offset angle to allow customization during surgery to better fit each patient. The modular neck features a standard taper consistent with various head options.

group.title: Synergy Hip System
group.description: Standard total hip arthroplasty (THA) using total hip system.

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

event.sub_title: Adverse soft tissue reaction secondary to dual taper from modular neck
Lysis over greater trochanter of total hip replacement
Degenerative changes with narrowing of the joint line and osteophytic changes
Radiographic review finding of 5mm stem subsidence from fibrous ingrowth hip stem
Stress shielding as indicated on radiographic findings CRF
Pain in anterior aspect of knee possible flare-up of scar tissue
L2-3,L4-5 Spinal stenosis;L5-S1 right-sided lateral recess stenosis, iatrogenic dural tear L4-5

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

event.sub_title: Reaction to metal debris/ metal allergy

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is less than or equal to 60 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: There was a decreased compliance rate at the 3-year follow-up visit and an increased termination rate by the 5-year follow-up visit resulting in smaller sample sizes for data collection.
